comment info:
Despite living atop a mountain alongside a large reservoir, I can't recall the last time we've had fog. Hurricane season came and went without much of the tropical storms that accompany even the mildest of storms. 

The hard, brown ground here isn't frozen; we've only had one or two hard frosts. It's dry, so much so that the smidges of rain and snow here and there haven't made a difference. In the dense forest that borders our land, the culled, blighted trees left on the ground two decades ago would provide perfect kindling. Townsfolk hold their collective breaths every time the fire station's alarm sounds. We fear the devastation that the smallest forest fire would wreak upon our rural town.  

It's odd that the map shared isn't from the publication date; more recent show most of southern New England and the Mid-Atlantic regions in severe or extreme drought. The severity plaguing the Great Plains and the Southwest is concerning but not surprising, particularly with the regions' population booms. But can weather patterns explain the major droughts around the Great Lakes and along the Atlantic?

I long for the comforting sound of steady rain on our roof, the quiet of a drizzly, cozy day.  Winter's frozen protection cannot come soon enough.
